description: Borrowed from Latin fimbriātus (“fibrous, fringed”), from fimbriae (“fibers, threads, fringe”) +‎ -ātus (“-ate”, adjectival suffix).

entries.meaning: (biology) Fringed, e.g. where the ends of a petal are split into two or more divisions.
examples: the fimbriate petals of the pink; the fimbriate end of the Fallopian tube

verbs.description: fimbriate (third-person singular simple present fimbriates, present participle fimbriating, simple past and past participle fimbriated)
